description: First attested in the 13th century as Middle English rancour, from Old French rancor, from Latin rancor (“rancidity, grudge, rancor”), from *ranceō (“I am rotten or putrid”), from which also English rancid.

entries.meaning: (American spelling) A feeling of long-lasting ire for another, sometimes to the point of hatred, over a perceived wrongdoing; bitterness.
examples: I could almost see the rancor in his eyes when he challenged me to a fight.
